definition: bad behaviour (especially of children) that is annoying but does not cause any serious damage or harm
the wish or tendency to behave or play in a way that causes trouble
harm or injury that is done to somebody or to their reputation
to hurt yourself physically
to do or say something deliberately to upset other people, or cause trouble between them
a separate section of a train for carrying passengers
a road vehicle, usually with four wheels, that is pulled by one or more horses and was used in the past to carry people
the act or cost of transporting goods from one place to another
a moving part of a machine that supports or moves another part, for example on a typewriter
the way in which somebody holds and moves their head and body
a railway truck for carrying goods
a vehicle with four wheels, pulled by horses or oxen and used for carrying heavy loads
a small table on very small wheels, used for carrying or serving food or drink
to not drink alcohol, either for a short time or permanently
a mixture of oil, vinegar and various herbs, etc., added to a salad
a special chair with wheels, used by people who cannot walk because of illness, an accident, etc.
a very large lorry
a large and powerful force or institution that cannot be controlled
to kill somebody, especially as a legal punishment
to do a piece of work, perform a duty, put a plan into action, etc.
to successfully perform an action or movement that requires skill
to make or produce a work of art
to follow the instructions in a legal document; to make a document legally acceptable
the study of speech sounds and how they are produced
a structure on which people, for example criminals, are killed by hanging
a machine, originally from France, for cutting people’s heads off. It has a heavy blade that slides down a wooden frame.
a device with a long blade for cutting paper or sheets of metal
the setting of a time limit on a debate in Parliament
very bad and unacceptable, often in a way that shocks people
extremely upset and anxious so that you cannot think clearly
a drink made of milk, and sometimes ice cream, with the added taste of fruit or chocolate, which is mixed or shaken until it is full of bubbles
the study of signs and symbols and of their meaning and use
a pale blue-green semi-precious stone
a pale blue-green colour
a clear precious stone of pure carbon, the hardest substance known. Diamonds are used in jewellery and also in industry, especially for cutting glass.
a shape with four straight sides of equal length and with angles that are not right angles
one of the four suits (= sets) in a pack of cards. The cards are marked with red diamond shapes.
one card from the suit called diamonds
the space inside the lines that connect the four bases; also used to mean the whole baseball field
to cheat somebody in order to get something, especially money, from them
to get money illegally from a person or an organization by tricking them
a trick; an act of cheating somebody
a convict (= a person who has been found guilty of a crime and sent to prison)
the advantages and disadvantages of something
excited, enthusiastic and full of energy
having or producing small bubbles of gas
having bubbles of gas in it
the study of style and the methods used in written language
a tune, especially the main tune in a piece of music written for several instruments or voices
a piece of music or a song with a clear or simple tune
the arrangement of musical notes in a tune
a series of musical notes that are sung or played in a particular order to form a piece of music
to be/not be singing or playing the correct musical notes to sound pleasant
to be/not be in agreement with somebody/something; to have/not have the same opinions, feelings, interests, etc. as somebody/something
to be the person who controls a situation
to express a different opinion or behave in a different way when your situation changes
to do whatever somebody tells you to
the person who provides the money for something can also control how it is spent
to behave in a different way from other people; to have different attitudes or ideas
to change your opinion about somebody/something or your attitude towards somebody/something
used to emphasize how much money something has cost
the theory and practice of writing dictionaries
causing a lot of angry public discussion and disagreement
public discussion and argument about something that many people strongly disagree about, think is bad, or are shocked by
the back part of the foot below the ankle
the part of a sock, etc. that covers the heel
the raised part on the bottom of a shoe, boot, etc. that makes the shoe, etc. higher at the back
having the type of heel mentioned
a pair of shoes that have high heels
the raised part of the inside of the hand where it joins the wrist
a man who is unpleasant to other people and cannot be trusted
following closely behind somebody
to force somebody to obey you and accept discipline
to make a dog come close to you
to agree to obey somebody and accept their orders
to come close to the person who has called it
to have to wait for somebody/something
to refuse to do something or to change your mind about something
to be deliberately slow in doing something or in making a decision
very close behind somebody/something; very soon after something
loving somebody very much
to have nothing to do while you are waiting for somebody/something
to be relaxed and enjoy yourself
to run away from somebody/something
to follow somebody closely
to turn around suddenly so that you are facing in the opposite direction
completely controlled by somebody
the loss of the ability to understand or produce speech, because of brain damage
the study of the history and origin of names, especially names of people
the process of preparing and using land for growing crops
land that is used for growing crops
the form of a language that is spoken in one area with grammar, words and pronunciation that may be different from other forms of the same language
great worry or fear about something unpleasant that may happen
